body:
Most Cygwin programs, including Python itself, accept Windows-style filenames: 
$ touch /tmp/foo.pyx
$ ll c:/cygwin64/tmp/foo.pyx
-rw-r--r-- 1 smith None 0 Apr 17 18:37 c:/cygwin64/tmp/foo.pyx
$ ll 'c:\cygwin64\tmp\foo.pyx'
-rw-r--r-- 1 smith None 0 Apr 17 18:37 c:\cygwin64\tmp\foo.pyx
$ python
Python 2.7.5 (default, Oct  2 2013, 22:34:09)
[GCC 4.8.1] on cygwin
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import os
>>> os.path.isfile('c:/cygwin64/tmp/foo.pyx')
True
>>> os.path.isfile('c:\\cygwin64\\tmp\\foo.pyx')
True
But Cython version 0.25.2 does not: 
$ pwd
/cygdrive/c/Users/smith
$ cython /tmp/foo.pyx  # Works
$ cython /cygdrive/c/cygwin64/tmp/foo.pyx  # Also works
$ cython c:/cygwin64/tmp/foo.pyx
[Errno 2] No such file or directory: '/cygdrive/c/Users/smith/c:/cygwin64/tmp/foo.pyx'
$ cython 'c:\cygwin64\tmp\foo.pyx'
[Errno 2] No such file or directory: '/cygdrive/c/Users/smith/c:\\cygwin64\\tmp\\foo.pyx'
$ cython '/cygdrive/c/cygwin64\tmp\foo.pyx'

Error compiling Cython file:
------------------------------------------------------------
...
^
------------------------------------------------------------

/cygdrive/c/cygwin64\tmp\foo.pyx:1:0: 'cygwin64\tmp\foo' is not a valid module name
Cython otherwise works perfectly well in a Cygwin environment, but this issue makes it awkward to call it from non-Cygwin Windows build tools.
title: Cygwin build doesn't accept Windows filenames
